roleset.name: match, mate together, couple

example.name: basic transitive
example.text: The architect matched the paint and the wallpaper

example.name: with-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the paint with the wallpaper

example.name: inverted with-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the wallpaper with the paint

example.name: to-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the paint to the wallpaper

example.name: inverted to-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the wallpaper to the paint

example.name: unaccusative
example.text: The paint and the wallpaper matched

example.name: tricky
example.text: The company matched Kodak's higher prices.

example.name: tricky nominal gerund in a NML node
example.text: There are also several national adjustments and network matching projects

example.name: ARG1 and ARG2
example.text: Here a pot - bellied Buddha is matched with a water ball .

roleset.note: MATCH-V NOTES: Member of VNcls amalgamate-22.2-1 (from match.01-v)
MATCH-N NOTES: Based on sentences in wsj. Comparison to match.01. VN class amalgamate-22.2-1. Framed by Katie. (from match.01-n)

The matched items all have the same status as arguments/semantic roles.There are passives(6a) The paint is matched (by the wallpaper)(6b) The wallpaper is matched (by the paint)but these are adjectival, not verbal, as the tests show: The paint was unmatched The paint is well matched*At noon, the paint was matched by the wallpaperTherefore, (6) are predicative sentences, and the participle is an adjective, just like "peeling." So the (optional) by-phrase is an adverbial; the noun in the by-phrase is not an A0 (agent) argument.(6a) The paint is [matched (by the wallpaper)] AdjP(6b) The wallpaper is [matched (by the paint)]AdjP (And therefore these cases are not to be tagged--Paul) (from match.01-v)

roleset.name: competition

example.name: with arg2
example.text: However, it wasn't until 1883, after a historic tournament in London, that a match for the title of strongest world player was first suggested.
example.arg: for the title of strongest world player

example.name: LOC
example.text: Also $ky have flooded TV with football , it is on constantly with at least 5 matches on at a weekend , and football every night with European matches .

example.name: args 0, 1, TMP, LOC
example.text: Richard Gasquet of France reacts during his match against Tommy Haas of Germany during the French Open tennis tournament at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris June 2, 2012.
example.arg: during the French Open tennis tournament
at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris

example.name: with arg3, argMs
example.text: On 6 January 1681, the first recorded boxing match took place in Britain when Christopher Monck, 2nd Duke of Albemarle (and later Lieutenant Governor of Jamaica) engineered a bout between his butler and his butcher with the latter winning the prize.

example.name: hypothetical competition
example.text: I can not help but recall the age old expression that Youth and Enthusiasim is no match against Wisdom and Treachery .

roleset.note: MATCH-N NOTES: Added by Julia based on BOLT, comparison to 'competition.01'. No VNcls. (from match.02-n)

roleset.name: match up

example.name: Without agent
example.text: When someone does n't do as well as they had hoped in a tea competition , they try to figure out [why]-1 their tea did n't match up with that of other growers *WHADVP*-1.

example.name: With agent
example.text: When I left him alone, he matched up the letters.

roleset.note: MATCH_UP-V NOTES: Added based on example in Brown corpus. similar to 'match.01'. Corresponds to VNcls amalgamate-22.2-1. Added by Julia. (from match.02-v)
Add as many arg1s as needed (from match.02-v)
